docs.snippet: There was an irregular trend in the foreign exchanges last week, changing the complexion of that market which had ruled firmly on light dealings for more than a month.
docs.lead_paragraph: There was an irregular trend in the foreign exchanges last week, changing the complexion of that market which had ruled firmly on light dealings for more than a month.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended Dec. 17, 1948

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 20 -- Disturbed by the recent series of military coups in Latin America, the United States has begun informal discussions on the Foreign Minister plane to ascertain how hemispheric democracy can be strengthened, it was...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 20 -- Disturbed by the recent series of military coups in Latin America, the United States has begun informal discussions on the Foreign Minister plane to ascertain how hemispheric democracy can be strengthened, it was learned today.
docs.abstract: US talks with various Foreign Mins on re-examining recognition policy reptd; Bogota Pact blamed for coups

headline.main: U.S. ACTS TO MODIFY HEMISPHERE VIEWS; Rightist Coups in Latin America Hint a Need to Re-examine Non-Recognition Policy

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: AMERICAN NATIONS AND WESTERN HEMISPHERE POSSESSIONS

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The State Department today condemned as "deplorable" the use of military force in Latin America for overthrowing popularly elected and constitutional governments.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The State Department today condemned as "deplorable" the use of military force in Latin America for overthrowing popularly elected and constitutional governments.

headline.main: U.S. DEPLORES WAVE OF AMERICAS' COUPS; State Department Opens Talks With Latin Lands in Hope of Curbing Army Revolts

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Council of the Organization of American States by resolution today called upon the Governments of Costa Rica and Nicaragua to abstain from any hostile act as a result of their border controversy.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Council of the Organization of American States by resolution today called upon the Governments of Costa Rica and Nicaragua to abstain from any hostile act as a result of their border controversy.
docs.abstract: Council asks CR and Nicaragua to end hostilities; tells CR to dissolve Caribbean Legion; blames invasion on CR pol exiles and says Nicaragua should have stopped it; CR says last invaders have fled

headline.main: Nicaragua and Costa Rica Told to Cease Hostile Acts; Resolution of Council of American States Also Calls for Action Against Invading Caribbean Legion by San Jose TWO LATIN NATIONS TOLD TO SHUN WAR

docs.snippet: THE year now closing brought to philately's gallery more portraits, figures and monuments of famous and obscure persons than in any earlier year in the hobby's annals. During 1948, postal tribute was accorded 163 men and women not previously...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE year now closing brought to philately's gallery more portraits, figures and monuments of famous and obscure persons than in any earlier year in the hobby's annals. During 1948, postal tribute was accorded 163 men and women not previously identified with stamp collecting.

headline.main: NEWS OF THE WORLD OF STAMPS; Great Number of Famous And Obscure Persons Honored in 1948

docs.snippet: TO postpone a Carnegie Hall debut for four years in order to make a South American and two nation-wide concert tours is unusual for a young pianist, but 20-year-old Byron Janis did just that. He rejected the plan of' his manager for an early Carnegie...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO postpone a Carnegie Hall debut for four years in order to make a South American and two nation-wide concert tours is unusual for a young pianist, but 20-year-old Byron Janis did just that. He rejected the plan of' his manager for an early Carnegie Hall recital, to follow the advice of his teachers and musical friends.

headline.main: PIANIST ON WAY UP; Janis, 20-Year-Old American, Toured Four Years Before New York Debut

docs.snippet: FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 26 -- In a rush of Christmas shopping, Western Germany's Allied officials negotiated trade treaties with six countries last week. These treaties were made with Sweden, the Netherlands, Turkey, Egypt, Poland and Spain.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 26 -- In a rush of Christmas shopping, Western Germany's Allied officials negotiated trade treaties with six countries last week. These treaties were made with Sweden, the Netherlands, Turkey, Egypt, Poland and Spain.

headline.main: 6 TREATIES SIGNED BY WESTERN ZONES; Allies in Germany Bring Total Trade Pacts to 20 in 1948 -- France Main Importer

byline.original: By JACK RAYMONDSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES
